The channel recently made a video taking a
look at all of the ways that Crash Team Racing
was changed over in Japan.

Like most other games in the franchise, Crash
Team Racing had quite a few changes made to

it in Japan to try and better appeal to Japanese
tastes.

In the video, I mentioned how the new remake
version of the game Nitro-Fueled hadn’t

been released in Japan yet and so it wasn’t
possible to fully compare the original game’s
changes to the new remake.

However, now that the game has been released,
we can take a look at the Japanese version
of the remake too.

If you missed the original game’s video,
you’ll be able to find a link in the description
below so you can check it out.

Like mentioned, there were a lot of changes
made to the original, but in the Remake, not

many changes has been made to the game at
all.

In fact, the overall Japanese localization
job has actually been met with some controversy

over in Japan due to it being seen as low
effort and quality.

As shown on the Japanese box art, the cover
was, like the original game, redesigned so
that it uses the Japanese design of Crash.

However, the box art is pretty much where
all changes end, aside from some language-related
matters.

Even on the game’s title screen, the game’s
name and logo was left completely untranslated
despite being translated on the box.

You may also recall how the original game
had a different name over in Japan and was

called “Crash Bandicoot Racing” rather
than “Crash Team Racing”.

The official Japanese name for the remake
is also Crash Bandicoot Racing, but this isn’t
reflected in-game.

One source of controversy relates to the game’s
voice acting and that, despite being dubbed,

the decision was made to recast the original
game’s voice actors.

In some cases, like for Nitros Oxide, this
couldn’t be helped due to the previous actor
passing away.

However, the game uses different actors for
other characters as well and this is despite

using the original actors for the Trilogy
remake.

And so this has made the experience a little
jarring for fans of the series.

Also, for a few characters like Crash and
Ripper Roo, the English dubbing is kept rather
than being localized like the original.

It is speculated amongst Japanese fans that
this may have been an attempt at trying to

cut costs on the localization and another
complaint from some players is that the translation

can sometimes be very literal and that this
can seem to make things either not make sense
or lose the charm from the original.

One thing that the Japanese version does is
that it sometimes adds subtitles at the bottom

of the screen when English graphics are shown
during scenes, like for this sign during the
intro, rather than changing the graphic itself.

However most other graphics are left both
untranslated and without subtitles, like the

book that polar is seen reading titled “How
To Drive”.

Like mentioned in the previous video, this
was actually translated in the original game
like most other graphics.

For example, the TNT crates were changed to
an image of a bomb, the Nitro crates were

translated to Japanese, and the CTR acronyms
were replaced due to the different title in
Japan.

All of this was kept the same as the English
versions in the new remake however.

One thing that the previous video didn’t
mention was a few other instances of translation

differences that could be found in the Japanese
version of the original – like in the endings,

which had some changes in Japan to presumably
again better appeal to Japanese audiences.

For example, in Crash’s original English
ending, it says that Crash went on to sell

his life story to a movie studio and the movie,
called “The “Color Orange” will be released
for the Christmas holiday season.

In Japan though, to briefly translate, it
talks about how thanks to everybody’s efforts,

peace was restored and Crash returned home
to his regular happy life.

Relating back to how, like previously mentioned,
the new translation is very literal, things

like this are now the same as in English for
the first time.

But, to finish, here are a few brief examples
of the Japanese voice acting.
First up is Nitros Oxide...
Then Aku Aku..
Then Uka Uka...
And then Coco...

And then lastly the four trophy girls as well
as Tawna...

Until next time, thank you for watching.
